review.title: Using Soft Computer Techniques on Smart Devices for Monitoring Chronic Diseases: the CHRONIOUS case
review.abstract: CHRONIOUS is an Open, Ubiquitous and Adaptive Chronic Disease Management Platform for Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease(COPD) Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) and Renal Insufficiency. It consists of several modules: an ontology based literature search engine, a rule based decision support system, remote sensors interacting with lifestyle interfaces (PDA, monitor touchscreen) and a machine learning module. All these modules interact each other to allow the monitoring of two types of chronic diseases and to help clinician in taking decision for cure purpose. This paper illustrates how some machine learning algorithms and a rule based decision support system can be used in smart devices, to monitor chronic patient. We will analyse how a set of machine learning algorithms can be used in smart devices to alert the clinician in case of a patient health condition worsening trend.

As a result of the exponential growth of hardware and software infrastructure, it is possible to rethink the entire approach to treating complex chronic diseases by limiting hospitalisation to a severe deterioration of the condition of the patient. sections.heading: III. THE PDA CHRONIOUS PREPROCESSING PHASE
sections.text: As already mentioned, the Personal Digital Assistant is a smartphone with WINDOWS MOBILE 6.5 operating system, an SQL SERVER 2005 COMPACT database and a.NET FRAMEWORK 3.5. Data collected by the PDA is as follows • data from the valuable jacket. • Responses to questionnaires on dietary habits, medication intake and lifestyle of the patient. • Data from the home patient monitor such as blood pressure, glucometer measurements and body weight. Once this data is collected, it is stored in the PDA database and a set of algorithms is triggered to analyze this data. As the PDA analyzes data for two different diseases, two sets of different algorithms are used. The basic data required for COPD treatment are ECG signals and respiratory data, so in the case of a COPD patient, we provide a first set of algorithms to process the electrocardioase pre-processing system at the end of the extraction phase, and then a specific feature is required to determine the extraction phase of the patient.

sections.heading: A. Preprocessing of COPD signals
sections.text: The aim of the pre-processing phase is to improve the overall quality of the ECG in order to enable more accurate analysis and measurements, as there is the possibility of having some sounds on the signals. • Possible noises in the signal include • Low frequency Base Line Wandering (BW) caused by breathing and body movements. • High frequency random noises caused by power interference (50 or 60Hz). • Muscle activity and random shifts in the ECG signal amplitude caused by poor electrode contacts and body movements. • Pre-processing includes: • Removal of ground line migrations (50 or 60Hz) signals that cause high frequency noise. • QRS detection, which is an extragenic low frequency activity that can disrupt signal analysis, making its clinical interpretation inaccurate and misleading.

sections.heading: V. CONCLUSIONS AN IMPROVEMENTS
sections.text: In this paper, we presented a set of machine learning algorithms storing in a smartphone that can be used in combination with some external devices and patients entered data for an initial monitoring / warning system to treat patients affected by chronic diseases. Dealing with telemedicine applications, this type of software could help improve the quality of life of the patient and could also be a valid help for the physician to enable more accurate monitoring of patient conditions without requiring the physical presence of the clinician. Apart from these potential benefits, a PDA equipped with this type of application may suffer some limitations. During the development phase, we face these problems: • Heavy resource consumption of pre-processing algorithms. • Updating a trained supervised algorithm can lead to a pre-processing algorithm for COPD parameters denoising is the most memory / CPU consumption.
